author: dirkjaeckel
content: Where can I find working bootstrap node enr records for Ethereum mainnet to use with a discv5 client? All ENR records I have found this far don't seem to work. Assuming an example like: `enr:/3.127.134.103:9000?udp=9000` should at least allow a tcp connection on port 9000.

author: dirkjaeckel
content: Thanks! This seems to be a good starting point.

author: parithosh
content:
You can compile devp2p (a tool that you get after running make all in geth's repo), then you can use that to ping:
```
./devp2p rlpx ping enode://22a8232c3abc76a16ae9d6c3b164f98775fe226f0917b0ca871128a74a8e9630b458460865bab457221f1d448dd9791d24c4e5d88786180ac185df813a68d4de@3.209.45.79:30303
```

author: dirkjaeckel
content: The port number 30303 looks like an execution layer nodes address. I am looking for beacon chain nodes.

author: popef
content: Yeah they look like EL nodes

author: dirkjaeckel
content: Does the first link really list discv5 enr records? The url says discv4 ðŸ˜•

author: popef
content: Getting from the CL client, like lighthouse, is also a good idea https://github.com/sigp/lighthouse/blob/stable/common/eth2_network_config/built_in_network_configs/mainnet/boot_enr.yaml

author: popef
content: Yeah, I think that's correct, but I'm afraid it may not really be used anywhere because go-ethereum is an EL client.

author: dirkjaeckel
content: This is what I am looking for! Thanks! Bootnodes by client software Great for debugging ðŸ™‚
